title: How to Season Brussels Sprouts

methods.name: Making Simple Brussels Sprouts with Salt, Pepper, and Spices

steps.headline: Rinse and trim the brussels sprouts.
steps.description: Run the brussels sprouts under cold water. Then trim off the end of the stem on each of them with a paring knife. Also remove any outer leaves that are discolored. Finally, cut the brussels sprouts in half lengthwise. Make sure to cut them in half lengthwise. This will ensure that the two halves don't fall apart because you will keep a part of the stem on each half.

steps.headline: Put the sprouts in a 4-quart pot.
steps.description: Add 1/2 cup water (120 mL) and 1/4 teaspoon (2 grams) of salt to the pot as well. Put the lid on the pot, put the pot on the stove, and then turn the heat to high. If you are cooking about 1 pound (0.45 kg) of brussels sprouts, a 4-quart pot should be big enough.Tip: This recipe doesn't require much water because you will leave the lid on, which will allow the steam created to cook the brussels sprouts through.

steps.headline: Cook the brussels sprouts with the lid on for 5 minutes.
steps.description: It's important to keep the lid on the entire time. Once the 5 minutes are up, check the doneness of the brussels sprouts with a sharp knife. If the knife slides into the center of the brussels sprouts easily, they are done cooking. In most cases, the brussels sprouts will be done in exactly 5 minutes, but if you like your brussels sprouts on the firm side, check their tenderness with a knife after about 4 minutes.

steps.headline: Add butter or oil to your brussels sprouts.
steps.description: Add a pad of butter or a drizzle of olive oil to the sprouts. This will add flavor and allow the other spices you add to stick to the sprouts. Flavorful oils, such as olive oil, are typically better for this than neutral oils, such as vegetable oil, because they add a richness and depth of flavor to the overall dish.

steps.headline: Sprinkle the sprouts with salt, pepper, and additional spices.
steps.description: Season the sprouts liberally with salt and pepper. Feel free to add any other spices you like, such as red pepper flakes, cayenne pepper, smoked paprika, or cumin. If you are nervous about trying to combine spices yourself, try using a pre-made spice blend, such as an Italian spice mix, a middle eastern spice mix or a seasoned salt mix. These are widely available at most grocery stores and can add a variety of complementary flavors to your brussels sprouts. The exact amount of pepper and spices you should add depends on your preferences. To start with, grab a pinch and sprinkle it evenly over the surface of all of your brussels sprouts.Tip: Since seasoning tastes can vary widely, you need to decide what is the right amount for you. Gradually add them and taste as you go so that you can get the flavor just right. Leftovers can be stored in an air-tight container in the fridge for up to a week.

methods.name: Roasting Brussels Sprouts With Garlic and Onion

steps.headline: Turn on your oven to 400 °F (204 °C) and get out a large cast-iron pan.
steps.description: Make sure the pan can easily fit all of the brussels sprouts you want to cook in one single layer. Roasting brussels sprouts at a high heat in a cast-iron pan allows the surface to caramelize while the center is cooked through.

steps.headline: Clean and trim your brussels sprouts.
steps.description: Take off any outer leaves that look discolored. Then trim off the tip of the stem to remove the dried end and rinse the sprouts under cool water. Finally, cut them in half lengthwise, so the leaves of each half are still attached to part of the stem. Cutting them is half will make it quicker for them to cook through and will give a flat surface to easily caramelize while in the oven.

steps.headline: Marinate the brussels sprouts before cooking them.
steps.description: Marinating can add a lot of flavor to your finished dish. Put your prepared brussels sprouts in a bowl and pour your marinade over them. Let them sit in the marinade for a half hour to an hour and then drain the excess marinade off right before cooking. You can use any marinade recipe you like but a marinade that consists of ½ cup (120 mL) olive oil, 1 tablespoon (16 grams) balsamic vinegar, 2 cloves of minced garlic, ½ teaspoon (4 grams) of onion powder, and a dash of salt and pepper will add saltiness and flavor to brussels sprouts that you plan on roasting.Tip: There are a variety of pre-made marinades that you can use on brussels sprouts. Look for one that is specifically made to be used on vegetables. They are typically available at almost any grocery store.

steps.headline: Sprinkle the brussels sprouts with your favorite spices.
steps.description: The flavor of brussels sprouts goes well with a wide variety of spices, ranging all the way from allspice to zaatar. For example, if you are roasting your brussels sprouts, sprinkle ¼ teaspoon (2 grams) of a spice like cumin or chili powder onto them before cooking to give them a deep, smoky flavor. If you are nervous about experimenting with a lot of spices, try adding just a dash of one spice you know you love in addition to the basic seasonings of olive oil and salt and pepper. To give brussels sprouts a bit of heat, sprinkle a pinch of red pepper flakes or cayenne powder onto them before roasting or sautéing them. For roasted brussels sprouts that have a wonderful fall flavor, sprinkle them with a light dusting of cinnamon and nutmeg, in addition to olive oil and salt and pepper.

steps.headline: Sauté the onion and garlic for about 5 minutes and then add the brussels sprouts.
steps.description: Heat 3-4 tablespoons (1.5-2 fl. oz) of olive oil in the cast-iron pan on your stove top. For 1 pound (0.45 kg) of brussels sprouts, add about a quarter of an onion and a few cloves of garlic, all chopped finely. Once the onions are beginning to become transparent, which should take about 5 minutes, add the brussels sprouts to the pan. Sautéing the garlic and onions before adding the sprouts will allow them to cook through, as the sprouts are quicker to cook. If you have shallots instead of onion you can use them interchangeably. Shallots are also excellent flavor enhancers for brussels sprouts.

steps.headline: Put the pan in the oven for 10-20 minutes.
steps.description: Move the brussels sprouts around so that the flat, cut side is face down in the pan. This will ensure that they get nice and browned. Check the sprouts beginning at about 10 minutes by piercing them with a sharp knife. If the knife slides through the sprout easily, they are done. Fully roasted Brussels sprouts will be a dark, rich brown, which means they will have lots of delicious flavor!

steps.headline: Add fresh herbs to your brussels sprouts after cooking them.
steps.description: Fresh herbs, such as chives and parsley, can add a lot of flavor and brightness to brussels sprouts. Chop up a few tablespoons (about 5 grams) of whatever herbs you have on hand and sprinkle them over your brussels sprouts right before serving. Some other fresh herbs that will go wonderfully with brussels sprouts include tarragon, thyme, oregano, cilantro, and sage.

steps.headline: Add additional salt and pepper, if necessary.
steps.description: Once the sprouts have been cooked, it’s important to taste them and assess whether you need more salt and pepper. If you added salt and pepper before cooking, you may not need any more at all. If you didn’t season before cooking, you will need to add a generous amount of salt and pepper. Store any leftovers in an air-tight container in the fridge for about a week.

methods.name: Making a Flavorful Raw Brussels Sprouts Salad

steps.headline: Clean and trim the brussels sprouts well.
steps.description: While brussels sprouts are usually cooked before being eaten, they can actually be consumed raw as well. To make them appetizing, take off any outer leaves that look discolored or wilted. Also trim the end of the stems to get rid of any dried up areas. Then rinse the sprouts in cold water to ensure that they are totally clean. It's important to clean all vegetables well, but it's especially important if you are planning on keeping them raw.

steps.headline: Cut the brussels sprouts very thinly.
steps.description: Cut each brussels sprout in half lengthwise. Then hold each half and cut down the sprout, making ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) slices. Be sure to cut the stem end very thinly so that you don't have large chunks in your salad.Raw brussels sprouts make a wonderful base for a salad when they are cut into thin strips. You can cut your brussels sprouts with a knife or a mandolin. If you use a mandolin, then there is no need to cut the sprouts in half first.

steps.headline: Massage 1/2 teaspoon (3 grams) of salt onto the shredded brussels sprouts.
steps.description: In order to season them and soften them up a bit for raw eating, sprinkle them with salt. Rub the salt into the surface of the sprouts with your fingers, breaking apart any pieces that are stuck together as you go. If you have about 1 pound (0.45 kg) of raw chopped or shaved brussels sprouts, 1/2 teaspoon (3 grams) of salt should be plenty to soften them and season them at the same time.

steps.headline: Add additional toppings to your brussels sprouts.
steps.description: Once your brussels sprouts have been prepared, consider adding toppings that will enhance their flavor. For instance, grating a bit of Parmesan cheese or sprinkling a bit of cooked, crumbled bacon on top of them will help season them and bring out their flavor. You can add any toppings that you would normally put in a slaw or green salad. This includes carrots, cucumbers, tomatoes, and green onions. If you are nervous about adding too much, add 1/4 cup, mix the salad, and then taste. If you add additional toppings gradually and keep tasting the salad, you can get the seasoning perfect.

steps.headline: Put a dressing on the brussels sprouts after you prepare them.
steps.description: A classic way to season vegetables is to put a dressing on them before serving. You can use a wide variety of sauces, such as a honey vinegar glaze, a simple béchamel, or garlic butter.Tip: When adding a dressing, remember that you have already salted the sprouts. Don't add one that is really salty to sprouts that are already salted. Using sauce for seasoning is especially good on raw brussels sprouts, as their firmness and bitterness can stand up well to a flavorful sauce. For instance, try a sauce that has cheese, nuts, or anchovies in it. Your brussels sprouts should store well in an air-tight container in the fridge for about a week.

Run the brussels sprouts under cold water.
Then trim off the end of the stem on each of them with a paring knife.
Also remove any outer leaves that are discolored.
Finally, cut the brussels sprouts in half lengthwise.

Put the sprouts in a 4-quart pot.
